abstract: The satire was only slightly less awkward than the real thing, in a freewheeling episode hosted by Adam Driver. Olivia Rodrigo was the musical guest.

Hours after it was announced that Elizabeth Magill, the president of the University of Pennsylvania, was resigning after an appearance before Congress in which she appeared to evade questions about whether students should be punished for calling for the genocide of Jews, “S.N.L.” led its broadcast with a satirical recreation of the Tuesday hearing.

abstract: In bitter debates from Israel to Africa to America, invoking a brutal history has become a powerful accusation.
lead_paragraph: The colonial era entered its death throes after World War II. From 1945 through the 1960s, a global order in which European powers took political control of other countries — occupying them with settlers, subjugating the local populations and exploiting the land and its inhabitants for economic gain — unraveled. Dozens of states in Asia and Africa threw off colonial overlords. Colonialism, once equated by the West with civilizing progress, became synonymous with iniquity.
headline: Who’s a ‘Colonizer’? How an Old Word Became a New Weapon
keywords: Colonization;Israel-Gaza War (2023- );International Relations;Politics and Government

abstract: Tragic tellings of the Shoah are all too common. The directors of “The Zone of Interest,” “Origin” and “Occupied City” refuse to let it live in the past.
lead_paragraph: In the British comedy “Extras,” Kate Winslet, who appears as a version of herself, is playing a nun in a film about the Holocaust. When commended for using her platform to bring attention to the atrocities, she replies callously, “I’m not doing it for that. I mean, I don’t think we really need another film about the Holocaust, do we?” She explains that she took the role because if you do a movie about the Holocaust, you’re “guaranteed an Oscar.”
headline: Can the Holocaust Movie Be Revelatory Again? 3 Filmmakers Say Yes.
keywords: Movies;Documentary Films and Programs;Holocaust and the Nazi Era;The Zone of Interest (Movie);Glazer, Jonathan;Origin (Movie);Caste: The Origins of Our Discontents (Book);DuVernay, Ava;Occupied City (Movie);Stigter, Bianca;McQueen, Steve (Filmmaker)

abstract: From the halls of Congress to America’s streets and universities, a once largely academic issue has roiled national discourse, inciting accusations of bigotry and countercharges of bullying.
lead_paragraph: The brutal shedding of Jewish blood on Oct. 7, followed by Israel’s relentless military assault on Gaza, has brought a fraught question to the fore in a moment of surging bigotry and domestic political gamesmanship: Is anti-Zionism by definition antisemitism?
headline: Is Anti-Zionism Always Antisemitic? A Fraught Question for the Moment.
keywords: Israel-Gaza War (2023- );Jews and Judaism;Zionism;Anti-Semitism;United States Politics and Government;audio-neutral-informative;Colleges and Universities

abstract: Republicans have been attacking elite universities for years. After a tense congressional hearing last week, many on the left are joining them.
lead_paragraph: For years, conservatives have struggled to persuade American voters that the left-wing tilt of higher education is not only wrong but dangerous. Universities and their students, they’ve argued, have been increasingly clenched by suffocating ideologies — political correctness in one decade, overweening “social justice” in another, “woke-ism” most recently — that shouldn’t be dismissed as academic fads or harmless zeal.
headline: As Fury Erupts Over Campus Antisemitism, Conservatives Seize the Moment
keywords: Israel-Gaza War (2023- );Colleges and Universities;Anti-Semitism;Discrimination;Censorship;Conspiracy Theories;Freedom of Speech and Expression;Race and Ethnicity;Conservatism (US Politics);Liberalism (US Politics);Democratic Party;Republican Party;Harvard University;University of Pennsylvania;Massachusetts Institute of Technology;Gay, Claudine;Kornbluth, Sally A;Magill, Elizabeth;Stefanik, Elise;Haley, Nikki R;DeSantis, Ron;United States

abstract: Earlier this year, mathematicians discovered a unique shape. Now do-it-yourselfers have found ingenious ways to put it to use.
lead_paragraph: It’s been a year of endless einsteins. In March, a troupe of mathematical tilers announced that they had discovered an “aperiodic monotile,” a shape that can tile an infinite flat surface in a pattern that does not repeat — “einstein” is the geometric term of art for this entity. David Smith, a shape hobbyist in England who made the original discovery and investigated it with three collaborators possessing mathematical and computational expertise, nicknamed it “the hat.” (The hat tiling allows for reflections: the hat-shaped tile and its mirror image.)
headline: What Can You Do With an Einstein?
keywords: Mathematics;Origami;London (England);your-feed-science

abstract: The race is on to put hotels in space and neighborhoods on the moon. Here’s some of what we know about how Earthlings fare beyond the safety of our home world.
lead_paragraph: As an incubator of life, Earth has a lot going for it, something we often fail to appreciate fully from within its nurturing bounds. Merely sending probes and rovers to the moon and Mars won’t do. For various reasons — adventure! apocalypse! commerce! — we insist upon taking our corporeal selves off-world too. Multiple private companies have announced plans to put hotels in space soon. NASA is aiming to 3-D-print lunar neighborhoods within a couple of decades. And while it will probably take longer than that to build and populate an outpost on Mars, preparations are being made: This summer, four NASA crew members began a 378-day stay in simulated Martian housing at the Johnson Space Center in Houston. Here’s some of what we know about how Earthlings fare beyond the safety of our home world.
headline: The Sunday Read: ‘The Bodily Indignities of the Space Life’
keywords: audio-neutral-informative;Titan (Saturn Moon);Mars (Planet);3-D Devices and Effects;Moon;National Aeronautics and Space Administration;Houston (Tex);Space and Astronomy

abstract: Help with housing costs eased the transition to a new home in Phoenix.
lead_paragraph: Twenty-three years ago, Abwe Songolo made the fateful decision to keep moving. It was August of 2000, and he had spent hours sailing across Lake Tanganyika from his hometown in the Democratic Republic of Congo to the city of Kigoma in Tanzania, where he had to live on the streets. He had escaped the war engulfing Congo, but Tanzania still felt too close to home. “I wanted to go as far as possible from Congo because of what I’d experienced,” he said. “Because I would have flashbacks of it.”
headline: A Refugee Finds Stability After Years of Flashbacks
keywords: Refugees and Displaced Persons;Philanthropy;International Rescue Committee;New York Times Communities Fund;Mozambique;United States

abstract: The proper response to censorship is not more censorship.

keywords: Israel-Gaza War (2023- );Colleges and Universities;Censorship;Anti-Semitism;Freedom of Speech and Expression;First Amendment (US Constitution);Harvard University;University of Pennsylvania;Massachusetts Institute of Technology;Stefanik, Elise;Kornbluth, Sally A;Gay, Claudine;Magill, Elizabeth

abstract: Rachel Goldberg’s adult son is still being held hostage by Hamas. “I have no clue how I am able to function,” she says.
lead_paragraph: Rachel Goldberg’s 23-year-old son, Hersh, was abducted by Hamas at a music festival in southern Israel on Oct. 7. In this interview with the Opinion editor Sarah Wildman, Ms. Goldberg reflects on the past two months of the crisis, the recent pause in fighting and the brief moments of “delicious, thankful respite” she felt as hostages returned home — even as her son remains captive. And she argues the hostage plight should be treated as a humanitarian crisis, not a political one.
headline: My Son Has Been Held Hostage by Hamas for 65 Days and Counting
keywords: audio-neutral-informative;Israel;Gaza Strip;Hamas;Terrorism;Kidnapping and Hostages;Israel-Gaza War (2023- );Goldberg-Polin, Hersh

abstract: Ministers should encourage people to do what our faith tells us to do over and over, which is to see the humanity in everyone, even our enemies.
lead_paragraph: I am ordained, but I do not pastor a church. Still, I am often invited to be a guest speaker or lecturer in congregations and universities. Lately, when people ask me questions afterward, they want to know my opinion about the war between Israel and Hamas. I am happy to answer them. Members of the clergy aren’t shut off from the world, and I don’t think our words should be either — we can be a force for good.
headline: The Theological Truth We Must Press During War
keywords: Israel-Gaza War (2023- );Clergy;Christians and Christianity;Civilian Casualties;Defense and Military Forces;Palestinians;Humanitarian Aid;Hamas;King, Martin Luther Jr;Gaza Strip;Israel

abstract: Mozart’s opera, tailored to families in this staging, is big on spectacle and let’s-put-on-a-show verve. What shines? Kathryn Lewek as Queen of the Night.
lead_paragraph: The evolution of Julie Taymor’s production of “Die Zauberflöte” from long-running hit to children’s-theater show at the Metropolitan Opera is now complete.
headline: Review: This ‘Magic Flute’ at the Met Lacks Some Luster
keywords: Opera;Classical Music;Mozart, Wolfgang Amadeus;Taymor, Julie;The Magic Flute (Opera)

abstract: A teacher and rabbi, he forged alliances across all branches of Judaism, and his scholarship confronted questions of Jewish tradition and modernity.
lead_paragraph: Rabbi David Ellenson, a scholar who wrestled with the interplay of tradition and modernity in Judaism and who shaped a generation of Reform rabbis as a teacher and later as the president of Hebrew Union College-Jewish Institute of Religion, died on Thursday at his home in Manhattan. He was 76.
headline: David Ellenson, 76, Who Guided a Generation of Reform Rabbis, Dies
keywords: Jews and Judaism;Rabbis;Deaths (Obituaries);Orthodox Judaism;Hebrew Union College-Jewish Institute of Religion;Ellenson, David

abstract: One day after the resignations of the university president and chairman, students and professors reflected on the continuing division at the school.
lead_paragraph: One day after the president of the University of Pennsylvania resigned over criticism that she did not condemn antisemitism forcefully enough, state leaders showed solidarity with Jews at a Philadelphia rally, while students and professors lamented the ongoing rift on campus.
headline: At Penn, Vacancies in Leadership, and Anguish on Campus
keywords: Israel-Gaza War (2023- );Jews and Judaism;Terrorism;Demonstrations, Protests and Riots;Palestinians;Casey, Robert P Jr;Magill, Elizabeth;Shapiro, Josh (1973- );Gaza Strip;Israel;Pennsylvania;Philadelphia (Pa)

abstract: Ms. Redstone waged a bitter battle for control of National Amusements, the parent company of MTV, CBS and the Paramount movie studio. Now, she’s considering a sale.
lead_paragraph: The media mogul Shari Redstone is in talks to sell a controlling stake in National Amusements, the parent company of the sprawling news and entertainment empire that includes the Paramount movie studio, CBS and MTV, according to three people familiar with the talks.
headline: Shari Redstone Is Said to Be in Talks to Sell Her Stake in Media Empire
keywords: Media;National Amusements Inc;Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures;Redstone, Shari;Television;Movies;Video Recordings, Downloads and Streaming;Cable Television;Paramount Pictures;CBS Corporation;Comcast Corporation;MTV Networks;Netflix Inc;Warner Bros Discovery;Ellison, David (1983- );Skydance Productions LLC;Paramount Global

abstract: Some border communities in the U.S. and Mexico are suddenly cut off from each other after a border crossing closed to cope with large numbers of migrants.
lead_paragraph: Like many people in the tiny town of Why, Ariz., Stephanie Fierro’s life revolves around the nearby border crossing. She works at a roadside café serving enchiladas to American tourists passing through on their way to beach resorts in Mexico. Her husband, a Mexican citizen, lives on the other side.
headline: To Handle a Surge of Illegal Crossings, Border Officials Stop Legal Ones
keywords: Arizona;Illegal Immigration;Immigration and Emigration;Border Barriers;Border Patrol (US);Hobbs, Kathleen M;Biden, Joseph R Jr;Why (Ariz);Ajo (Ariz);Mexican-Americans;United States Politics and Government

abstract: The tap dancer Caleb Teicher and the beatboxer Chris Celiz have expanded an earlier collaboration into an evening-length work at the Joyce Theater.
lead_paragraph: The acclaimed tap dancer Caleb Teicher and the world-champion beatboxer Chris Celiz might seem to belong to very different tribes. But when they met a few years ago while separately performing at a conference in Miami, they got to talking about what their art forms had in common.
headline: ‘Bzzz’ Turns Art Forms of Solo Virtuosity Into a Group Affair
keywords: Dancing;Joyce Theater;Bzzz (Dance);Celiz, Chris (Musician);Teicher, Caleb

abstract: Despite government efforts to silence her, she drew global attention to an epidemic that devastated rural China and killed tens of thousands.
lead_paragraph: Gao Yaojie, a Chinese doctor who defied government pressure in exposing an AIDS epidemic that spread across rural China through reckless blood collection, died on Sunday at her home in Upper Manhattan. She was 95.
headline: Dr. Gao Yaojie, Who Exposed AIDS Epidemic in Rural China, Dies at 95
keywords: Gao Yaojie;Deaths (Obituaries);Blood Donation;Acquired Immune Deficiency Syndrome;Henan Province (China);China;Rural Areas

abstract: The Los Angeles Dodgers are betting $700 million that Shohei Ohtani can deliver championships and help increase revenue. But the economics of sports can be fickle.
lead_paragraph: Japanese baseball players are taught to keep a low profile and let their performances do the talking. Yet for more than a decade, Shohei Ohtani has been willing to make waves.
headline: Ohtani’s Contract Goes Beyond Dollars and Sense
keywords: Ohtani, Shohei;Los Angeles Dodgers;Baseball;Wages and Salaries;Japan

abstract: Scammers have used QR codes to steal personal information by imitating legitimate companies or sending deceptive emails and text messages, the Federal Trade Commission said.
lead_paragraph: QR codes, the square bar codes that can be scanned and read by smartphones, are seemingly used everywhere: to board flights, enter concerts and look at restaurant menus.
headline: That QR Code You’re About to Scan Could Be Risky, F.T.C. Warns
keywords: Bar Codes;Computer Security;Smartphones;Privacy;Mobile Applications;Text Messaging;Federal Trade Commission;Consumer Protection

abstract: The president was back on the fund-raising trail in Los Angeles this weekend after a hiatus because of the writers’ and actors’ strikes.
lead_paragraph: President Biden is facing multiple wars, economic anxieties, the indictment of his son and flagging poll numbers. But he was received in California this weekend like a superstar, headlining the hottest events in Los Angeles.
headline: Biden Steps Out in Tinsel Town and the Big Donors Show Up
keywords: Biden, Joseph R Jr;Katzenberg, Jeffrey;Campaign Finance;Trump, Donald J;Presidential Election of 2024;Democratic Party

abstract: Donald J. Trump has changed his mind about returning to the witness stand on Monday to testify in his own defense.
lead_paragraph: Donald J. Trump has decided not to return to the witness stand to testify on Monday as he had planned, setting up an abrupt and anticlimactic ending to the defense’s case in his civil fraud trial in Manhattan.
headline: Trump Will Not Testify as Scheduled in Civil Fraud Trial
keywords: New York State Civil Case Against Trump (452564/2022);Frauds and Swindling;Deutsche Bank AG;Engoron, Arthur F;James, Letitia;Trump, Donald J;New York State

abstract: Plus, Shohei Ohtani’s $700 million contract
lead_paragraph: U.N. officials warned yesterday that pressure was mounting near Gaza’s border with Egypt, where tens of thousands of Palestinians have tried to flee Israel’s military campaign.
headline: Monday Briefing: The U.N. and W.H.O.’s Dire Gaza Warnings

abstract: Storms and tornadoes left a swath of destruction that included parts of Clarksville, where three people died, and near Nashville, where three others were killed.
lead_paragraph: Reed Arnold was watching TV on Saturday at his home in Clarksville, Tenn., when he saw a warning on his phone. He stepped outside and filmed the swiftly moving clouds and a looming tornado. Minutes later, the twister hit his neighborhood.
headline: Six Dead and More Than 60 Injured After Severe Weather in Tennessee
keywords: Weather;Deaths (Fatalities);Tornadoes;Clarksville (Tenn);Davidson County (Tenn);Jackson (Miss);Mississippi;Tennessee

abstract: A former liberal government official, he saw little chance of full reconciliation with Palestinians in “the foreseeable future” but nevertheless sought to ease tensions.
lead_paragraph: Shlomo Avineri, an Israeli political scientist, historian and former government official whose pessimism about resolving the conflict with Palestinians did not stop him from advocating measures to ease it, died on Nov. 30 in Jerusalem. He was 90.
headline: Shlomo Avineri, Israeli Scholar Skeptical About Peace, Dies at 90
keywords: AVINERI, SHLOMO;Deaths (Obituaries);International Relations;Palestinians;Israel-Gaza War (2023- );Israel;Haaretz;Books and Literature;Writing and Writers

abstract: Officials announced that the Ukrainian president would travel to Washington on Tuesday for a last-ditch lobbying effort with President Biden and members of Congress.
lead_paragraph: President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine will travel to Washington on Tuesday for a last-ditch lobbying effort with President Biden and members of Congress aimed at securing billions of dollars of U.S. aid, officials said on Sunday.
headline: Zelensky to Visit Washington With U.S. Aid to Ukraine in Doubt
keywords: United States Politics and Government;Russian Invasion of Ukraine (2022);United States International Relations;Biden, Joseph R Jr;Zelensky, Volodymyr;Johnson, Mike (1972- );Russia;Ukraine

abstract: The special counsel Jack Smith told the judge she should keep the trial’s start date in March and continue making decisions as the former president appeals one of her rulings.
lead_paragraph: Federal prosecutors on Sunday asked the judge handling former President Donald J. Trump’s trial on charges of plotting to overturn the 2020 election to reject his request to freeze the case in its entirety as Mr. Trump appeals her recent ruling that he is not immune from prosecution.
headline: Prosecutors Ask Judge to Deny Trump’s Request to Freeze Election Case
keywords: Federal Criminal Case Against Trump (2020 Election Case);Presidential Election of 2020;Special Prosecutors (Independent Counsel);United States Politics and Government;Justice Department;Chutkan, Tanya S;Smith, Jack (Attorney);Trump, Donald J;Windom, Thomas P
